\section{III.H Zeroth Order Hydrodynamics}

As a first approximation, we shall assume that in local equilibrium, the density f1f_{1}f1​ at each point in space can be represented as in eq.(III.56), i.e.

f10(p⃗,q⃗,t)=n(q⃗,t)(2πmkBT(q⃗,t))3/2exp⁡[−(p⃗−mu⃗(q⃗,t))22mkBT(q⃗,t)]f_{1}^{0}(\vec{p}, \vec{q}, t)=\frac{n(\vec{q}, t)}{\left(2 \pi m k_{B} T(\vec{q}, t)\right)^{3 / 2}} \exp \left[-\frac{(\vec{p}-m \vec{u}(\vec{q}, t))^{2}}{2 m k_{B} T(\vec{q}, t)}\right]f10​(p​,q​,t)=(2πmkB​T(q​,t))3/2n(q​,t)​exp[−2mkB​T(q​,t)(p​−mu(q​,t))2​]

h⃗0=0\vec{h}^{0}=0h0=0

The conservation laws in this approximation take the simple forms

{Dtn=−n∂αuαmDtuα=Fα−1n∂α(nkBT)DtT=−23T∂αuα\left\{\begin{array}{l} D_{t} n=-n \partial_{\alpha} u_{\alpha} \\ m D_{t} u_{\alpha}=F_{\alpha}-\frac{1}{n} \partial_{\alpha}\left(n k_{B} T\right) \\ D_{t} T=-\frac{2}{3} T \partial_{\alpha} u_{\alpha} \end{array}\right.⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​Dt​n=−n∂α​uα​mDt​uα​=Fα​−n1​∂α​(nkB​T)Dt​T=−32​T∂α​uα​​

In the above expression, we have introduced the material derivative

Dt≡[∂t+uβ∂β]D_{t} \equiv\left[\partial_{t}+u_{\beta} \partial_{\beta}\right]Dt​≡[∂t​+uβ​∂β​]

which measures the time variations of any quantity as it moves along the stream-lines set up by the average velocity field u⃗.\vec{u} .u. By combining the first and third equations, it is easy to get

Dtln⁡(nT−3/2)=0D_{t} \ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)=0Dt​ln(nT−3/2)=0

The quantity ln⁡(nT−3/2)\ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)ln(nT−3/2) is like a local entropy for the gas (see eq.(III.67)), which according to the above equation is not changed along stream-lines. The zeroth order hydrodynamics thus predicts that the gas flow is adiabatic. This prevents the local equilibrium solution of eq.(III.93) from reaching a true global equilibrium form which necessitates an increase in entropy.

To demonstrate that eqs.(III.97) do not describe a satisfactory approach to equilibrium, examine the evolution of small deformations about a stationary (u⃗0=0)\left(\vec{u}_{0}=0\right)(u0​=0) state, in a uniform box (F⃗=0)(\vec{F}=0)(F=0), by setting

{n(q⃗,t)=nˉ+ν(q⃗,t)T(q⃗,t)=Tˉ+θ(q⃗,t)\left\{\begin{array}{l} n(\vec{q}, t)=\bar{n}+\nu(\vec{q}, t) \\ T(\vec{q}, t)=\bar{T}+\theta(\vec{q}, t) \end{array}\right.{n(q​,t)=nˉ+ν(q​,t)T(q​,t)=Tˉ+θ(q​,t)​

It is easy to check that this equation has the following modes, the first three with zero frequency:

(a) Two modes describe shear flows in a uniform (n=nˉ)(n=\bar{n})(n=nˉ) and isothermal (T=Tˉ)(T=\bar{T})(T=Tˉ) fluid, in which the velocity varies along a direction normal to its orientation (e.g. u⃗=f(x,t)y^)\vec{u}=f(x, t) \hat{y})u=f(x,t)y^​). In terms of Fourier modes k⃗⋅u⃗T(k⃗)=0\vec{k} \cdot \vec{u}_{T}(\vec{k})=0k⋅uT​(k)=0, indicating transverse flows that are not relaxed in this zeroth order approximation.

(b) A third zero frequency mode describes a stationary fluid with uniform pressure P=P=P= nkBT.n k_{B} T .nkB​T. While nnn and TTT may vary across space, their product is constant, insuring that the fluid will not start moving due to pressure variations. The corresponding eigenvector of eq.(III.103) is

ve=(nˉ0−Tˉ)\mathbf{v}_{\mathbf{e}}=\left(\begin{array}{c} \bar{n} \\ 0 \\ -\bar{T} \end{array}\right)ve​=⎝⎛​nˉ0−Tˉ​⎠⎞​

(c) Finally, the longitudinal velocity (u⃗ℓ∥k⃗)\left(\vec{u}_{\ell} \| \vec{k}\right)(uℓ​∥k) combines with density and temperature variations in eigenmodes of the form

vl=(nˉ∣k⃗∣ω(k⃗)23Tˉ∣k⃗∣), with ω(k⃗)=±vℓ∣k⃗∣\mathbf{v}_{\mathbf{l}}=\left(\begin{array}{c} \bar{n}|\vec{k}| \\ \omega(\vec{k}) \\ \frac{2}{3} \bar{T}|\vec{k}| \end{array}\right), \quad \text { with } \quad \omega(\vec{k})=\pm v_{\ell}|\vec{k}|vl​=⎝⎜⎜⎛​nˉ∣k∣ω(k)32​Tˉ∣k∣​⎠⎟⎟⎞​, with ω(k)=±vℓ​∣k∣

where

vℓ=5kBTˉ3v_{\ell}=\sqrt{\frac{5 k_{B} \bar{T}}{3}}vℓ​=35kB​Tˉ​​

is the longitudinal sound velocity. Note that the density and temperature variations in this mode are adiabatic, i.e. the local entropy (proportional to ln⁡(nT−3/2))\left.\ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)\right)ln(nT−3/2)) is left unchanged.

We thus find that none of the conserved quantities relaxes to equilibrium in the zeroth order approximation. Shear flow and entropy modes persist forever, while the two sound modes have undamped oscillations. This is a deficiency of the zeroth order approximation which is removed by finding a better solution to the Boltzmann equation.

\section{III.I First Order Hydrodynamics}

While f10(p⃗,q⃗,t)f_{1}^{0}(\vec{p}, \vec{q}, t)f10​(p​,q​,t) of eq.(III.93) does set the right hand side of the Boltzmann equation to zero, it is not a full solution, as the left hand side causes its form to vary. The left hand side is a linear differential operator, which using the various notations introduced in the previous sections, can be written as

L[f]≡[∂t+pαm∂α+Fα∂∂pα]f=[Dt+cα∂α+Fαm∂∂cα]f\mathcal{L}[f] \equiv\left[\partial_{t}+\frac{p_{\alpha}}{m} \partial_{\alpha}+F_{\alpha} \frac{\partial}{\partial p_{\alpha}}\right] f=\left[D_{t}+c_{\alpha} \partial_{\alpha}+\frac{F_{\alpha}}{m} \frac{\partial}{\partial c_{\alpha}}\right] fL[f]≡[∂t​+mpα​​∂α​+Fα​∂pα​∂​]f=[Dt​+cα​∂α​+mFα​​∂cα​∂​]f

It is simpler to examine the effect of L\mathcal{L}L on ln⁡f10\ln f_{1}^{0}lnf10​. which can be written as

ln⁡f10=ln⁡(nT−3/2)−mc22kBT−32ln⁡(2πmkB)\ln f_{1}^{0}=\ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)-\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T}-\frac{3}{2} \ln \left(2 \pi m k_{B}\right)lnf10​=ln(nT−3/2)−2kB​Tmc2​−23​ln(2πmkB​)

Using the relation ∂(c2/2)=cβ∂cβ=−cβ∂uβ\partial\left(c^{2} / 2\right)=c_{\beta} \partial c_{\beta}=-c_{\beta} \partial u_{\beta}∂(c2/2)=cβ​∂cβ​=−cβ​∂uβ​, we get

L[ln⁡f10]=Dtln⁡(nT−3/2)+mc22kBT2DtT+mkBTcαDtuα+cα(∂αnn−32∂αTT)+mc22kBT2cα∂αT+mkBTcαcβ∂αuβ−FαcαkBT\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}\left[\ln f_{1}^{0}\right] &=D_{t} \ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)+\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T^{2}} D_{t} T+\frac{m}{k_{B} T} c_{\alpha} D_{t} u_{\alpha} \\ &+c_{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial_{\alpha} n}{n}-\frac{3}{2} \frac{\partial_{\alpha} T}{T}\right)+\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T^{2}} c_{\alpha} \partial_{\alpha} T+\frac{m}{k_{B} T} c_{\alpha} c_{\beta} \partial_{\alpha} u_{\beta}-\frac{F_{\alpha} c_{\alpha}}{k_{B} T} \end{aligned}L[lnf10​]​=Dt​ln(nT−3/2)+2kB​T2mc2​Dt​T+kB​Tm​cα​Dt​uα​+cα​(n∂α​n​−23​T∂α​T​)+2kB​T2mc2​cα​∂α​T+kB​Tm​cα​cβ​∂α​uβ​−kB​TFα​cα​​​

If the fields n,Tn, Tn,T, and uαu_{\alpha}uα​, satisfy the zeroth order hydrodynamic eqs.(III.97), we can simplify the above equation to

L[ln⁡f10]=0−mc23kBT∂αuα+cα[(FαkBT−∂αnn−∂αTT)+(∂αnn−32∂αTT)−FαkBT]+mc22kBT2cα∂αT+mkBTcαcβuαβ=mkBT(cαcβ−δαβ3c2)uαβ+(mc22kBT−52)cαT∂αT\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}\left[\ln f_{1}^{0}\right] &=0-\frac{m c^{2}}{3 k_{B} T} \partial_{\alpha} u_{\alpha}+c_{\alpha}\left[\left(\frac{F_{\alpha}}{k_{B} T}-\frac{\partial_{\alpha} n}{n}-\frac{\partial_{\alpha} T}{T}\right)+\left(\frac{\partial_{\alpha} n}{n}-\frac{3}{2} \frac{\partial_{\alpha} T}{T}\right)-\frac{F_{\alpha}}{k_{B} T}\right] \\ &+\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T^{2}} c_{\alpha} \partial_{\alpha} T+\frac{m}{k_{B} T} c_{\alpha} c_{\beta} u_{\alpha \beta} \\ &=\frac{m}{k_{B} T}\left(c_{\alpha} c_{\beta}-\frac{\delta_{\alpha \beta}}{3} c^{2}\right) u_{\alpha \beta}+\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T}-\frac{5}{2}\right) \frac{c_{\alpha}}{T} \partial_{\alpha} T \end{aligned}L[lnf10​]​=0−3kB​Tmc2​∂α​uα​+cα​[(kB​TFα​​−n∂α​n​−T∂α​T​)+(n∂α​n​−23​T∂α​T​)−kB​TFα​​]+2kB​T2mc2​cα​∂α​T+kB​Tm​cα​cβ​uαβ​=kB​Tm​(cα​cβ​−3δαβ​​c2)uαβ​+(2kB​Tmc2​−25​)Tcα​​∂α​T​

The characteristic time scale τU\tau_{U}τU​ for L\mathcal{L}L is extrinsic, and can be made much larger than τ×.\tau_{\times} .τ×​. where we have kept only the leading term. Thus the first order solution is given by (using eq. ((( III. 110))) )

where τμ=τK=τ×\tau_{\mu}=\tau_{K}=\tau_{\times}τμ​=τK​=τ×​ in the single collision time approximation. However, in writing the above equation, we have anticipated the possibility of τμ≠τK\tau_{\mu} \neq \tau_{K}τμ​=τK​ which arises in more sophisticated treatments (although both times are still of order of τ×)\left.\tau_{\times}\right)τ×​)

It is easy to check that ∫d3p⃗f11=∫d3p⃗f10=n\int d^{3} \vec{p} f_{1}^{1}=\int d^{3} \vec{p} f_{1}^{0}=n∫d3p​f11​=∫d3p​f10​=n, and thus various local expectation values are calculated to first order as

⟨O⟩1=1n∫d3p⃗Of10(1+g)=⟨O⟩0+⟨gO⟩0\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle^{1}=\frac{1}{n} \int d^{3} \vec{p} \mathcal{O} f_{1}^{0}(1+g)=\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle^{0}+\langle g \mathcal{O}\rangle^{0}⟨O⟩1=n1​∫d3p​Of10​(1+g)=⟨O⟩0+⟨gO⟩0

The calculation of averages over products of cαc_{\alpha}cα​ 's, distributed according to the Gaussian weight of f10f_{1}^{0}f10​, is greatly simplified by the use of Wick's theorem, which states that expectation value of the product is the sum over all possible products of paired expectation values, for example

(Expectation values involving a product of an odd number of cαc_{\alpha}cα​ 's are zero by symmetry.) Using this result, it is easy to verify that

⟨pαm⟩1=uα−τK∂βTT⟨(mc22kBT−52)cαcβ⟩0=uα\left\langle\frac{p_{\alpha}}{m}\right\rangle^{1}=u_{\alpha}-\tau_{K} \frac{\partial_{\beta} T}{T}\left\langle\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T}-\frac{5}{2}\right) c_{\alpha} c_{\beta}\right\rangle^{0}=u_{\alpha}⟨mpα​​⟩1=uα​−τK​T∂β​T​⟨(2kB​Tmc2​−25​)cα​cβ​⟩0=uα​

The pressure tensor at first order is given by

(Using the above result, we can further verify that ε1=⟨mc2/2⟩1=3kBT/2\varepsilon^{1}=\left\langle m c^{2} / 2\right\rangle^{1}=3 k_{B} T / 2ε1=⟨mc2/2⟩1=3kB​T/2, as before. ))) Finally, the heat flux is given by

hα1=n⟨cαmc22⟩1=−nmτK2∂βTT⟨(mc22kBT−52)cαcβc2⟩0=−52nkB2TτKm∂αT\begin{aligned} h_{\alpha}^{1} &=n\left\langle c_{\alpha} \frac{m c^{2}}{2}\right\rangle^{1}=-\frac{n m \tau_{K}}{2} \frac{\partial_{\beta} T}{T}\left\langle\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{2 k_{B} T}-\frac{5}{2}\right) c_{\alpha} c_{\beta} c^{2}\right\rangle^{0} \\ &=-\frac{5}{2} \frac{n k_{B}^{2} T \tau_{K}}{m} \partial_{\alpha} T \end{aligned}hα1​​=n⟨cα​2mc2​⟩1=−2nmτK​​T∂β​T​⟨(2kB​Tmc2​−25​)cα​cβ​c2⟩0=−25​mnkB2​TτK​​∂α​T​

At this order, we find that spatial variations in temperature generate a heat flow that tends to smooth them out, while shear flows are opposed by the off-diagonal terms in the pressure tensor. These effects are sufficient to cause relaxation to equilibrium, as can be seen by examining the modified behavior of the modes discussed previously. (a) The pressure tensor now has an off-diagonal term

Pα≠β1=−2nkBTτμuαβ≡−μ(∂αuβ+∂βuα)P_{\alpha \neq \beta}^{1}=-2 n k_{B} T \tau_{\mu} u_{\alpha \beta} \equiv-\mu\left(\partial_{\alpha} u_{\beta}+\partial_{\beta} u_{\alpha}\right)Pα=β1​=−2nkB​Tτμ​uαβ​≡−μ(∂α​uβ​+∂β​uα​)

where μ≡nkBTτμ\mu \equiv n k_{B} T \tau_{\mu}μ≡nkB​Tτμ​ is the viscosity coefficient. A shearing of the fluid (e.g. described by a velocity uy(x,t))\left.u_{y}(x, t)\right)uy​(x,t)) now leads to a a viscous force that opposes it (proportional to μ∂x2uy)\left.\mu \partial_{x}^{2} u_{y}\right)μ∂x2​uy​), causing its diffusive relaxation as discussed below.

(b) Similarly, a temperature gradient leads to a heat flux

h⃗=−K∇T\vec{h}=-K \nabla Th=−K∇T

where K=(5nkB2TτK)/(2m)K=\left(5 n k_{B}^{2} T \tau_{K}\right) /(2 m)K=(5nkB2​TτK​)/(2m) is the coefficient of thermal conductivity of the gas. If the gas is at rest (u⃗=0\left(\vec{u}=0\right.(u=0, and uniform P=nkBT)\left.P=n k_{B} T\right)P=nkB​T), variations in temperature now satisfy

n∂tε=32nkB∂tT=−∂α(−K∂αT),⇒∂tT=2K3nkB∇2Tn \partial_{t} \varepsilon=\frac{3}{2} n k_{B} \partial_{t} T=-\partial_{\alpha}\left(-K \partial_{\alpha} T\right), \quad \Rightarrow \quad \partial_{t} T=\frac{2 K}{3 n k_{B}} \nabla^{2} Tn∂t​ε=23​nkB​∂t​T=−∂α​(−K∂α​T),⇒∂t​T=3nkB​2K​∇2T

This is the Fourier equation and shows that temperature variations relax by diffusion. We can discuss the behavior of all the modes by linearizing the equations of motion. The first order contribution to Dtuα≈∂tuαD_{t} u_{\alpha} \approx \partial_{t} u_{\alpha}Dt​uα​≈∂t​uα​ is

δ1(∂tuα)≡1mn∂βδ1Pαβ≈−μmnˉ(13∂α∂β+δαβ∂γ∂γ)uβ\delta^{1}\left(\partial_{t} u_{\alpha}\right) \equiv \frac{1}{m n} \partial_{\beta} \delta^{1} P_{\alpha \beta} \approx-\frac{\mu}{m \bar{n}}\left(\frac{1}{3} \partial_{\alpha} \partial_{\beta}+\delta_{\alpha \beta} \partial_{\gamma} \partial_{\gamma}\right) u_{\beta}δ1(∂t​uα​)≡mn1​∂β​δ1Pαβ​≈−mnˉμ​(31​∂α​∂β​+δαβ​∂γ​∂γ​)uβ​

where μ≡nˉkBTˉτμ.\mu \equiv \bar{n} k_{B} \bar{T} \tau_{\mu} .μ≡nˉkB​Tˉτμ​. Similarly, the correction for DtT≈∂tθD_{t} T \approx \partial_{t} \thetaDt​T≈∂t​θ, is given by

δ1(∂tθ)≡−23kBn∂αhα≈−2K3kBnˉ∂α∂αθ\delta^{1}\left(\partial_{t} \theta\right) \equiv-\frac{2}{3 k_{B} n} \partial_{\alpha} h_{\alpha} \approx-\frac{2 K}{3 k_{B} \bar{n}} \partial_{\alpha} \partial_{\alpha} \thetaδ1(∂t​θ)≡−3kB​n2​∂α​hα​≈−3kB​nˉ2K​∂α​∂α​θ

with K=(5nˉkB2TˉτK)/(2m)K=\left(5 \bar{n} k_{B}^{2} \bar{T} \tau_{K}\right) /(2 m)K=(5nˉkB2​TˉτK​)/(2m). After Fourier transformation, the matrix equation (III.103) is modified to

ω(νuαθ)=(0nˉδαβkβ0kBTˉmnˉδαβkβ−iμmnˉ(k2δαβ+kαkβ3)kBmδαβkβ023Tˉδαβkβ−i2Kk23kBnˉ)(νuβθ)\omega\left(\begin{array}{c} \nu \\ u_{\alpha} \\ \theta \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & \bar{n} \delta_{\alpha \beta} k_{\beta} & 0 \\ \frac{k_{B} \bar{T}}{m \bar{n}} \delta_{\alpha \beta} k_{\beta} & -i \frac{\mu}{m \bar{n}}\left(k^{2} \delta_{\alpha \beta}+\frac{k_{\alpha} k_{\beta}}{3}\right) & \frac{k_{B}}{m} \delta_{\alpha \beta} k_{\beta} \\ 0 & \frac{2}{3} \bar{T} \delta_{\alpha \beta} k_{\beta} & -i \frac{2 K k^{2}}{3 k_{B} \bar{n}} \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c} \nu \\ u_{\beta} \\ \theta \end{array}\right)ω⎝⎛​νuα​θ​⎠⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎛​0mnˉkB​Tˉ​δαβ​kβ​0​nˉδαβ​kβ​−imnˉμ​(k2δαβ​+3kα​kβ​​)32​Tˉδαβ​kβ​​0mkB​​δαβ​kβ​−i3kB​nˉ2Kk2​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​⎝⎛​νuβ​θ​⎠⎞​

We can ask how the normal mode frequencies calculated in the zeroth order approximation are modified at this order. It is simple to verify that the transverse (shear) normal models (k⃗⋅u⃗T=0)\left(\vec{k} \cdot \vec{u}_{T}=0\right)(k⋅uT​=0) now have a frequency

ωT=−iμmnˉk2\omega_{T}=-i \frac{\mu}{m \bar{n}} k^{2}ωT​=−imnˉμ​k2

The imaginary frequency implies that these modes are damped over a characteristic time τT(k)∼1/∣ωT∣∼(λ)2/(τμvˉ2)\tau_{T}(k) \sim 1 /\left|\omega_{T}\right| \sim(\lambda)^{2} /\left(\tau_{\mu} \bar{v}^{2}\right)τT​(k)∼1/∣ωT​∣∼(λ)2/(τμ​vˉ2), where λ\lambdaλ is the corresponding wavelength, and vˉ∼kBT/m\bar{v} \sim \sqrt{k_{B} T / m}vˉ∼kB​T/m​ is a typical gas particle velocity. We see that the characteristic time scales grow as the square of the wavelength, which is characteristic of diffusive processes.

In the remaining normal modes the velocity is parallel to k⃗\vec{k}k, and eq.(III.125) reduces

to

ω(νuℓθ)=(0nˉk0kBTˉmnˉk−i4μk23mnˉkBmk023Tˉk−i2Kk23kBnˉ)(νuβθ)\omega\left(\begin{array}{c} \nu \\ u_{\ell} \\ \theta \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & \bar{n} k & 0 \\ \frac{k_{B} \bar{T}}{m \bar{n}} k & -i \frac{4 \mu k^{2}}{3 m \bar{n}} & \frac{k_{B}}{m} k \\ 0 & \frac{2}{3} \bar{T} k & -i \frac{2 K k^{2}}{3 k_{B} \bar{n}} \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c} \nu \\ u_{\beta} \\ \theta \end{array}\right)ω⎝⎛​νuℓ​θ​⎠⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎛​0mnˉkB​Tˉ​k0​nˉk−i3mnˉ4μk2​32​Tˉk​0mkB​​k−i3kB​nˉ2Kk2​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​⎝⎛​νuβ​θ​⎠⎞​

The determinant of the dynamical matrix is the product of the three eigen-frequencies, and to lowest order is given by

det⁡(M)=i2Kk23kBnˉ⋅nˉk⋅kBTˉkmnˉ+O(τ×2)\operatorname{det}(M)=i \frac{2 K k^{2}}{3 k_{B} \bar{n}} \cdot \bar{n} k \cdot \frac{k_{B} \bar{T} k}{m \bar{n}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau_{\times}^{2}\right)det(M)=i3kB​nˉ2Kk2​⋅nˉk⋅mnˉkB​Tˉk​+O(τ×2​)

At zeroth order the two sound modes have ω±0(k)=±vℓk\omega_{\pm}^{0}(k)=\pm v_{\ell} kω±0​(k)=±vℓ​k, and hence the frequency of the isobaric mode is

ωe1(k)≈det⁡(M)−vℓ2k2=−i2Kk25kBnˉ+O(τ×2)\omega_{e}^{1}(k) \approx \frac{\operatorname{det}(M)}{-v_{\ell}^{2} k^{2}}=-i \frac{2 K k^{2}}{5 k_{B} \bar{n}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau_{\times}^{2}\right)ωe1​(k)≈−vℓ2​k2det(M)​=−i5kB​nˉ2Kk2​+O(τ×2​)

At first order, the longitudinal sound modes also turn into damped oscillations with frequencies ω±1(k)=±vℓk−iγ.\omega_{\pm}^{1}(k)=\pm v_{\ell} k-i \gamma .ω±1​(k)=±vℓ​k−iγ. The simplest way to obtain the decay rates is to note that the trace of the dynamical matrix is equal to the sum of the eigenvalues, and hence

ω±1(k)=±vℓk−ik2(2μ3mnˉ+2K15kBnˉ)+O(τ×2)\omega_{\pm}^{1}(k)=\pm v_{\ell} k-i k^{2}\left(\frac{2 \mu}{3 m \bar{n}}+\frac{2 K}{15 k_{B} \bar{n}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau_{\times}^{2}\right)ω±1​(k)=±vℓ​k−ik2(3mnˉ2μ​+15kB​nˉ2K​)+O(τ×2​)

The damping of all normal modes guarantees the, albeit slow, approach of the gas to its final uniform and stationary equilibrium state. MIT OpenCourseWare

noteIndex.body:
# Introduction to Tex Decks!

TexDeck.net is a collection of resources assembled to make LaTeX rich flashcards easier to write, remix, and organize.

The effect: Low cost active learning, allowing one's knowledge of science to scale sustainably.

A [[case study]] is in progress to seed the flashcard repository using a course in [nanoelectronics](https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-701-introduction-to-nanoelectronics-spring-2010/) from [OpenCourseWare](https://ocw.mit.edu/)

((ref:[[case study.1 motivation]]))

### How does the system work?

....

### Intellectual Property

All work is [CC-BY-SA 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) unless otherwise specified at the top of a page. I cannot really enforce the attribution clause, but I do highly reccomend it. If you find these resources useful, consider sharing them with others.

Also, keep in mind that this is a work in progress and may contain errors. [Pull requests on these study resources](https://github.com/Stedag/ocwphy) are encouraged.

Despite accumulating a good deal of notes as part of my B.S. I will not include any of school notes among these resources to honor copyright agreements with my department. Nonetheless I forsee monotonic aggregation of resources organized around OCW classes or open-access textbooks.

For any concerns regarding IP, open an issue on github.
